citations.narrative:
The indoor enclosure used to temporarily house three adult African penguins did not contain a pool or water feature with
enough surface area or depth to allow the birds to immerse, bath or swim in the water. The only water features included
an approximately 1.5ft X 2ft plastic tub filled with approximately 3 inches of water and a 2ft X 2ft bowl with approximately 3
inches of water. Additionally, the animal care staff is spraying/misting the penguins a minimum of three times daily.
According to facility staff these penguins have been housed in this enclosure since 04/09/2025 and may be kept here for
at least two more weeks while construction repairs are being completed on their outdoor enclosure. Although there were
no indications of stress or abnormal behavior in these animals at time of inspection, failure to provide these aquatic birds
with pools of appropriate size and depth inhibits their expression of natural behaviors and may potentially cause stress
and behavioral or medical issues.
Primary enclosures housing wading and aquatic birds must contain a pool or other aquatic area (e.g., ponds, waterfalls,
fountains, and other water features) and a dry area that allows easy ingress or egress of the pool or other aquatic area.
Pools and other aquatic areas must be of sufficient surface area and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural
and social adjustments, such as immersion, bathing, swimming, and foraging, with adequate freedom of movement and
freedom to escape from aggression demonstrated by other birds in the enclosure.
Correct by 04/19/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
